utterances: Hello.
How are you, Alex?
I'm well.
What do you make of this fund-raising total for Fred Thompson?
Well, I think it's damaging, but not fatal at all.
One of the most difficult parts about the preseason now is navigating the fun house mirror world of expectations.
You know, the campaign goes out and says we're going do five, which means they think they can do six and a half, and they ultimately only do three and a half.
So the good news is, it's a lot of money.

The bad news is, the people who kind of monitor how you're doing before the voters turn on here in the preseason, you've kind of failed at that three and half to meet your expectation of five so you take a little hit on it.

And it's compounded by the fact there's been a lot of kind of coverage in the last 20 or so days about how the Fred Thompson pre-campaign campaign, exploratory committee, has had some personnel changes, and eyebrows are raising among the expectation centers - is Fred really in trouble?
All of this is something he can solve by getting in the race and performing well.
But the kind of fan dance that he's been doing to kind of tease the process is now running out of steam.
Well, the expectations have been pretty good.
I mean, this guy has been on the cover of a lot of magazines, and he's supposed to be the savior, isn't he?
Well, yeah.
No, I think he'd be an impressive candidate, but he's got to become a candidate and go up there and be impressive.

The problem with the expectations game is you dress up in a Superman suit and you go out there and say I can lift locomotives and get a lot of applause, and there's a lot of hoopla, but eventually somebody says, okay, Superman, lift up that locomotive.

And so Fred, who's done a great job of kind of creating a buzz about his campaign, which has not had to endure the burden of answering tricky press questions or really being out there as a candidate, is now kind of (unintelligible) where the rubber hits the road, and fundraising is one of those things.
You mentioned word over the last couple of weeks - people leaving his campaign and some people writing that there's a problem because his wife is trying to manage his campaign.
What are you hearing inside the party about that?

You know, the preseason that we're in now loves gossip, and nothing is more fun to gossip about than spouses throwing frying pans around a campaign and yelling at everybody, which I think is a disservice to her.
Jeri is a smart, very capable person, but I think some of the breathless speculation is a little overdone.
Most voters in the primaries make their decision at the end, so this preseason stuff, while important, I think can be a little bit overanalyzed.
And the Thompson campaign in particular is almost a parody of this.
He's not even an announced candidate.
He's running an exploratory committee, yet announcing fundraising totals like candidates do and being judged on expectations success, like a candidate.

If you were advising Senator Thompson on what to say in the next couple of days about this, would you tell him, look, move up your date, call a press conference for next week in Tennessee and say I'm in?
Well, I will tell the first to announce that he's going to focus on L.A.
traffic problems as I sit here in a traffic jam on Santa Monica Boulevard.

But after he (unintelligible) with that canny maneuver, I would tell him to have a 30-day rollout plan, start talking about big things in an organized way, and I'd pull the trigger on that with a little more teasing in August and probably spark it off around Labor Day.

He's got to fill the vacuum with his own narrative as a candidate or the vacuum will get filled for him with gossip of whether or not his wife fired an advance man for, you know, bringing the wrong kind of ham sandwich, whatever the rumor of the day is.
Watching politics with the Republican political consultant Mike Murphy - stuck in traffic in L.A.
Mike, thanks for being with us again.
Thank you very much, Alex.
And you actually say this campaign is now reminding you of the 1990s in a way that I hadn't thought about before I read your piece.
There's no question about it that Mr. Murtha obviously emboldened the Democrats.
He gave them cover, as you mentioned, Farai, as a former Marine, as former decorated - or is a former decorated veteran.
And he looks like he's probably going to be the minority whip - or, excuse me, the majority whip.
And so having said that, it's going to be a very interesting tight walk for the Democrats to walk over the next two years.
Very quickly.
We don't have much time.
What are the Republicans going to do to try to get the black vote since it still overwhelmingly went for Democrats?
Well, you know it's interesting because Michael Steele, who was the Republican nominee in Maryland, has expressed an interest in running the Republican National Committee next year.
And he would be a very attractive candidate.
He obviously has experience in doing this.
He was the Republican chairman in Maryland for about four years.
Very articulate, charismatic spokesperson for our party.
And if in fact he is the nominee, the president's choice to run the Republican National Committee, I think he's going to give Democrats a run for their money.
There's no question about it.
Look, Democrats overwhelmingly voted for Democratic candidates this last election, and we need to do an even better job of reaching out to African-Americans.
And I got to give credit to Ken Mehlman.
He's done a very good job, the current chairman of the Republican National Committee has done a very good job.
Robert, unfortunately we're going to have to leave it there.
We're out of time.
That's no problem.
You could tell I feel passionately about this.
Thank you very much, Robert.
GOP political strategist Robert Traynham is a regular contributor to Political Corner.
And coming up, caught on tape.
The FBI investigates an alleged beating by the LAPD, and we remember R&B great Gerald Levert.
This is Day to Day.
I'm Deborah Amos.
We don't often hear much about Zimbabwe, but conditions in this Southern African country are dire.
There's hardly any fuel, and people there often have to scrounge for a loaf of bread.
Many blame longtime President Robert Mugabe for the economic crisis, but few dare say that publicly.
In the city of Bulawayo, a group of women is challenging the government at great risk and at great cost.
The group calls itself WOZA - Women of Zimbabwe Arise.
Its leader invited a young reporter, whom we'll identify later, along for quite a ride.
(Soundbite of vehicle)
We are going to safe house where we live and work.
I am being driven very quickly through some quiet suburbs in one of the largest cities in Zimbabwe.
We have to make sure we don't get followed whenever we go there.
I'm in the backseat and the two women with me look as nervous as I feel.
Our mandate is street protests in Zimbabwe, to hold the government accountable.
And this is a government that does not respect a mother's right to call for a better Zimbabwe, and when we go in the street doing that, they get a little bit peeved at us.
The driver is Jenny Williams and she belongs to a women's rights group called WOZA, standing for Women of Zimbabwe Arise.
Quite a few people know my face and most people know the kind of work I do.
She has been beaten and arrested more than 20 times by Zimbabwean police for protesting in the streets.
Now she is a wanted woman.
It's the most asked question of any of our members who are in custody - where does Jenny live?
(Soundbite of footsteps)
Jenny has been sleeping in safe houses like this for over a year.
The movement she and other Zimbabwean women formed to protect their rights has become an international inspiration and a thorn in the Zimbabwe government's side.
Most of our members feel that if they are going to be dying, can they not die silently?
Days later I get a call.
The WOZA women will march in the center of town.
My driver and I dress for jail.
We dress warmly with many layers of clothing because it's winter here and jail is cold.
(Soundbite of vehicle)
We reached the spot where the protesters told us they would meet and wait.
We are early but all we see is ordinary people going about their business.
Suddenly, seemingly out of nowhere, the crowd of ordinary pedestrians quickly assembles.
More come out of shops and cars.
Now they are holding banners and posters and shouting.
I spot Jenny Williams in the front leading the chant.
(Soundbite of protesters)
All of a sudden the crowd scatters.
Through the ducking, scurrying women, I see a single Zimbabwean policeman flailing his baton wildly.
He strikes at anything that moves.
More police arrive, outfitted in full riot attire.
The sun is beating down and sweat or tears are clouding my vision.
The loud smacking noises of iron on soft skin and rubber on skulls is a sound I will never forget.
I am so engrossed and appalled at the sight that I do not see the truck full of riot police barreling down on me.
Like a swarm of angry wasps, they screech to a halt and pile out.
One grabs me by my jacket; the other yanks the equipment out my hands.
They start beating.
After a couple of whacks, the commander looks at me in fury and demands to know why I was taking pictures.
When I don't answer, another grabs me by my hair and smashes the back of my head with his baton.
One slaps me and calls me stupid; then I am thrown on the back of their truck.
They all sit around me as we drive off.
They take me back me back to the police station.
After some negotiating by my driver, who followed us the whole way, they release me but not my equipment.
Perhaps they thought I was a tourist.
Maybe they thought I was a foreigner.
I have no idea.
I just know that I am very, very lucky.
